contents.context:
To mark the International Day of Families on May 15th, the United Nations Human Rights Office in Seoul urged the two Koreas to enable separated families to meet and make permanent contact.
The office on Friday posted on Twitter a call for both Koreas to allow contact among separated families, through meetings, letters and phone calls.
It also emphasized that around 65-percent of the separated families who are still alive are in their 80s or older.
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
UN Human Rights Office urges two Koreas to allow permanent contact between separated families
Updated: 2020-05-16 14:13:34 KST

contents.context:
We begin with an update on the COVID-19 situation here in the nation.
South Korea has confirmed 19 new COVID-19 cases on Saturday.
So far, a total of 162 people have been infected from the Itaewon cluster infections.
That includes a new fourth-hand infectionwhich went from nightclub to customers, then to their acquaintances, next to a karaoke facility and from there to a new patient.
It brings the total number of confirmed cases 11-thousand and 37.
With two additional deaths, the death toll now stands at 262.
Meanwhile, the number of COVID-19 patients across the globe has topped 4.5 million as of Friday.
According to Johns Hopkins University, three quarters are from the U.S. and Europe. The global death toll stands at over 305-thousand.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea confirms 19 new COVID-19 cases on Sat., death toll at 262
Updated: 2020-05-16 13:02:23 KST

contents.context:
After almost three months of delay, civil service exams for grade 5 public officials and diplomat candidates are being held today in South Korea amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
Around 12-thousand people are taking the exams.
Everyone entering the test locations went through a temperature check and were required to use hand sanitizers and wear masks.
In each room, 15 test-takers sit with a one-and-a-half meter of distance between them.
Applicants subject to self-quarantine were also allowed to take the test in a separate location with 4 supervisors.

Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Civil service exams for grade 5 public officials and diplomat candidates being held today in S. Korea amid COVID-19 pandemic
Updated: 2020-05-16 11:51:49 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's oldest coronavirus patient, a woman 1-hundred-and-four years old, has fully recovered, and on Friday left the hospital.
She was discharged from Pohang Medical Center, 67 days after she was admitted.
The medical team there celebrated her discharge, and said they hope her recovery inspires other elderly patients fighting the disease.
Reporter : reina5467@gmail.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean woman aged 104 fully recovers from COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-16 10:11:22 KST

contents.context:
Elementary school teacher Shin Seung-hee is sitting in an empty classroom, recording a video for her online classes.
She asks questions, but there are no students there to answer them.
The school semester has been further delayed due to the recent cluster infection of COVID-19 from Seoul's Itaewon neighborhood.

(SOV_KOREAN - )
"Does it look the same or is there a difference? () Okay."

Teachers haven't even met their students face-to-face yet.

(KOREAN - )
"Although I haven't had the chance to get to know you guys, I hope you can resume your normal daily routines."

The students' absence is more noticeable than ever as South Korea celebrates Teachers' Day on May 15th.
A small computer screen is not enough to get close to students.

(KOREAN - )
" It used to be a huge pleasure to receive letters and drawings from my students, so I feel so sad."

A teacher about to start her first year teaching cannot wait to meet her first students.

(KOREAN - ) ,
"I try my best to do what I can at the moment so I can be more helpful for my students later on."

However, even the COVID-19 outbreak couldn't stop students from showing their appreciation to their teachers.
During livestreamed online classes, students prepared special events.
They made love heart gestures over the screen, and each student wrote down one letter on the paper to spell out the message "I love you teacher, Thank you for taking care of us."
Most people did not get to celebrate the day face-to-face, but still many of them enjoyed the day in this unique way, while waiting to finally meet each other for the first time.
Kim Sung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea marks Teachers' Day, but scene is different due to COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-16 10:11:11 KST

contents.context:
Catastrophic.
That’s how second-year paramedic Kim Soo-jung describes the COVID-19 crisis.
At the peak of the epidemic, more than 300 COVID-19 patients were being moved to hospitals every day across South Korea.

(Korean- )
“Overall, it was a social disaster. The number of patients kept skyrocketing but Daegu didn’t have enough hospitals or ambulances to deal with all the people.”

Helping Daegu in its time of need were the huge number of firefighters who came in from all over the country.
More than 900 firefighters descended on the city and moved close to seven-and-a-half-thousand patients during the pandemic.

(Korean- pip)
“Seeing hundreds of ambulances gathered in the same place for the first time and all the paramedics speaking different dialects from different regions was overwhelming. We only had one aim: to send patients to a safe environment.”

Gearing up was physically grueling.
She had to go through the so-called 5 steps: putting on her protective suit, pulling on her overshoes, wearing goggles, a mask and gloves.

(Korean- )
"When you have all this stuff on, it's very hard to hear and see. Above all, as the day warmed up, the protective suit got so sweaty and stuffy.”

What helped her overcome those difficulties and focus on the task at hand was her sense of duty.

(Korean- )
“Being a firefighter is about serving citizens and saving people in danger. That's the reason I decided to become a firefighter and that's what made me endure the discomfort.”

Daegu has now largely flattened the curve thanks to the hard work of medical staff, fire fighters and the city's citizens. With Seoul seeing another big community-based transmission, she says it's time for the country to pull together again.
She added the challenging times Daegu went through provided invaluable experience about how to systematically respond to the crisis.
Choi Jeong-yoon, Arirang News, Daegu.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
How paramedics in Daegu, S. Korea battled against COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-16 10:10:34 KST

contents.context:
High school seniors will start returning to classrooms schools from Wednesday.
In case a student is found with COVID-19 symptoms, the National Fire Agency will have additional emergency medical staff on stand by to transport the individual to test sites at each of the 224 fire stations nationwide.
Every station will have at least one ambulance set aside exclusively to take students to the test site and home.
Such measures are aimed at reducing the burden on students and their parents, while preventing community spread of the virus.
Reporter : jiyeonkim@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Medical staff set aside to transfer COVID-19 suspected students to test sites
Updated: 2020-05-16 10:10:00 KST

contents.context:
As of noon Friday, South Korea has confirmed 153 cases of COVID-19 linked to the Itaewon clubs and bars.
Among those, 90 were infected at the clubs and the other 63 are family, friends and coworkers who caught the virus either second- or third-hand.
It's not just clubs, though some of the latest cases happened at singing rooms.
According to the Seoul city government, five people have been infected in the neighborhood of Hongdae, an area popular with young people.
They had not been to Itaewon, but one of them had been in the same singing room, or noraebang, as someone who had.
These are third-degree infections, and the government is determined to stop it from going any farther.

"Our top priority is to prevent a fourth-level transmission, so that's why we are doing our best to trace and manage contacts with the infected. So far, there have been no cases or indications of fourth-degree infections."

In terms of age, 15 people confirmed with the virus are younger than 18.
Some of them were infected by their teacher at a private academy in Incheon.
Meanwhile, the government is going to hold a briefing next Tuesday on guidelines for high-risk facilities like clubs, which right now are closed.
And since the weather is warming up, that will include guidelines on air conditioning in public places.
As of Friday, the total number of cases reported in South Korea stands at 11,18.
And as of Thursday at 6 PM, almost 37-thousand people were in self-quarantine, a number that's been rising since the Itaewon outbreak was first discovered.
Jang Tae-hyun, Arirang News
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea reports 153 COVID-19 cases linked to Seoul nightlife district
Updated: 2020-05-15 17:10:24 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in expressed his appreciation and respect for the nation's educators.
On social media, he thanked teachers for comforting and supporting their students while schools have been closed and for guiding the students on a new path of learning through online classes.
The president also vowed to capitalize on the country's IT power to upgrade the remote education infrastructure.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
President Moon expresses thanks to teachers to mark Teachers' Day
Updated: 2020-05-15 17:04:37 KST

contents.context:
South Korea reported 27 new cases of COVID-19 on Friday, … more than half of them them part of the cluster infections linked to nightclubs in Seoul.
This marks the eighth straight day of double-digit increases.
Five of the cases were imported, and of the local infections, 14 were in Seoul.
Total infections in South Korea now stand at eleven,18.
The country reported no new COVID-19 deaths, …leaving the death toll at two-hundred-60.
Nearly 20-thousand people are being tested.
Reporter :
contents.headline:
S. Korea reports 27 new COVID-19 cases Friday following club cluster infections
Updated: 2020-05-15 13:19:24 KST

contents.context:

contents.context:
As officials in South Korea scramble to test, track and trace potential carriers of the coronavirus, the Seoul Metropolitan Government says it will begin its own emergency inspection rounds starting today through next month.
They will focus on English kindergartens and private academies that specialize in preparing kids for their college entrance exams.

(KOREAN)
"We have set up special inspection guidance for 612 kindergartens and academies. We'll also thoroughly inspect facilities for their compliance to 'everyday life quarantine.'"
(612 , ' ' ..)

Kindergartens and institutions that do not abide by the guidelines will face administrative action.
English kindergartens have been operating despite school closures as they are classified as private language centers.
The move comes as an instructor in Incheon was confirmed to have transmitted the virus to students, parents and a fellow instructor.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Seoul city to begin emergency COVID-19 inspections on English kindergartens, private academies
Updated: 2020-05-15 10:04:37 KST
